meanings.def: a person who you think behaves or speaks in a way that lacks intelligence or good judgement
examples: Don't be such a fool!
I felt a fool when I realized my mistake.
He told me he was an actor and I was fool enough to believe him.
Like a fool, I told her everything.
Stop behaving like a fool!
That fool of a doctor has prescribed me the wrong medicine!
The poor fool was imprisoned on my account.
They had left me looking like a fool.
You silly little fool!
You're an even bigger fool than I thought.
You must take me for a fool!

meanings.def: (in the past) a man employed by a king or queen to entertain people by telling jokes, singing songs, etc.
examples: court fools who used to provide entertainment in the royal court

meanings.def: a cold light dessert (= a sweet dish) made from fruit that is cooked to make it soft and mixed with cream or custard
examples: rhubarb fool

meanings.def: to behave in a stupid way in order to make people laugh, especially in a way that may also annoy them
examples: Quit playing the fool and get some work done!
Stop acting the fool and be serious!
He thought that being an actor only involved tap dancing and playing the fool.

meanings.def: used to say that something is very easy to do
examples: Any fool could tell she was lying.

meanings.def: to be too intelligent or know too much about something to be tricked by other people
examples: She's nobody's fool when it comes to dealing with difficult patients.
She's nobody's fool. She had the car checked by a mechanic before buying it.

meanings.def: a person who is not sensible usually spends money too quickly or carelessly, or is cheated by others
people with little experience try to do the difficult or dangerous things that more experienced people would not consider doing
to say or do something deliberately so that people will think that somebody is stupid
examples: Can't you see she's making a fool of you?
I will not be made a fool of like this.
She was angry at having been made a fool of.
She is accused of attempting to cheat the taxman.
He cheated his way into the job.
Just don’t be fooled into investing any money with them.
She deceived him into handing over all his savings.
She felt betrayed when she found out the truth about him.
I was taken in by her story.
They had been conned out of £100 000.

meanings.def: to do something stupid that makes other people think that you are a fool
examples: I made a complete fool of myself in front of everyone!

meanings.def: used to say that you think that somebody was stupid to do something, especially when it causes them problems
examples: ‘He's not an easy person to live with.’ ‘More fool her for marrying him!’
‘I know I shouldn’t have given him the money, but I did.’ ‘More fool you!’
I thought it was safe to leave my suitcase there. More fool me.

meanings.def: an older person who behaves in a stupid way is worse than a younger person who does the same thing, because experience should have taught him or her not to do it
to be very impatient with people that you think are stupid
examples: She was a forceful personality who didn't suffer fools gladly.

meanings.def: to trick somebody into believing something that is not true
examples: fool somebody You don't fool me!
She certainly had me fooled—I really believed her!
fool yourself You're fooling yourself if you think none of this will affect you.
fool somebody into doing something Don't be fooled into thinking they're going to change anything.
She's not easily fooled.
Ha! Fooled you! You really thought I was going to jump, didn't you?
She had me completely fooled for a moment.
You can't fool me with all that nonsense!
I'm not easily fooled by anyone, least of all you.
He fooled them into thinking he was a detective.
Just don't be fooled into investing any money with them.

meanings.def: to say or do stupid or silly things, often in order to make people laugh
examples: fool (about/around) Stop fooling around and sit down!
fool about/around with something If you fool about with matches, you'll end up getting burned.

meanings.def: used to say that you do not believe something that somebody has just told you
examples: ‘I'm trying as hard as I can!’ ‘You could have fooled me!’

idioms.def: used to say that you do not believe something that somebody has just told you
examples: ‘I'm trying as hard as I can!’ ‘You could have fooled me!’

meanings.def: showing a lack of intelligence or good judgement
examples: That was a damn fool thing to do!
That fool husband of mine locked us out of the house.
